Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A New Framework for Fine-grained Soil Characterization (Moving Beyond Atterberg Limits)

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to modernize geotechnical index testing by exploring a new approach for fine-grained soil characterization based on automated and rapid measurements of water vapor sorption behavior. Unlike historical methods that have relied on cumbersome manually-determined indices only indirectly related to clay composition such as Atterberg?s limits, the new framework will be based on fundamental clay surface properties including specific surface area (SSA) and cation exchange capacity (CEC). Despite recognition that SSA and CEC are linked to macroscopic clay behavior, their usage has seen limited application in geotechnical practice because these links remain uncertain and measurement methods remain complex. New methods will be developed to derive these basic clay properties using sorption-based procedures that are more systematic, economical, and readily automated than existing techniques. Intellectual contributions will be made by exploring the concept of an intrinsic water vapor sorption isotherm unique to all clays and by improving basic understanding of linkages between clay surface properties and macroscopic behavior.

Development of a new fine-grained soil characterization framework will transform the way geotechnical site investigations are performed and improve the efficiency with which geotechnical engineering projects are executed. A fundamentally sound approach for expansive soil characterization will alleviate the severe economic and social burden of damages resulting from these materials. The framework will allow design engineers to more effectively quantify site variability by allowing a larger and more diverse suite of samples to be tested in a short amount of time and at lower cost than existing methods. Improved basic understanding of fine-grained soil behavior will impact the broad range of applications where these materials have found use, including environmental applications such as waste containment, filtration and membranes, and as industrial adsorbents. Education and outreach initiatives will be integrated with the research to capitalize on the collaborative nature of the project, including a graduate student exchange program, a diversity initiative, and an educational initiative featuring integration of sorption-based soil classification modules into undergraduate geotechnical engineering laboratory courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to modernize geotechnical engineering practice by exploring a new approach for fine-grained and expansive soil characterization based on automated and rapid measurements of water vapor sorption behavior. Unlike historical methods that have relied on cumbersome manually-determined indices only indirectly related to clay composition such as Atterberg limits, the proposed characterization framework is based on fundamental clay surface properties including specific surface area (SSA) and cation exchange capacity (CEC). New methods have been developed to derive these basic clay properties using sorption-based procedures that are more systematic, economical, and readily automated than existing techniques, most of which have seen very limited application in geotechnical research and practice. The established characterization framework now can quantitatively identify both SSA and CEC directly from vapor sorption isotherm data and have been validated against the standardized methods. The framework could fundamentally transform the way geotechnical site investigations are performed and could dramatically improve the efficiency with which they are executed. There are total 8 peer-reviewed journal papers and one conference paper published from and acknowledged this project.

Damage and litigation costs from construction of roads, bridges, and buildings on expansive soils total billions of dollars each year in the US alone, yet the current state of mitigation practice still relies heavily on antiquated, uncertain, and highly empirical site characterization methods. The developed framework can classify expansive soil by using the water vapor sorption isotherm and the comparisons with the existing classification methods are consistently good. The proposed characterization framework pave the way to more effectively quantify variability at such sites by allowing a much larger and more diverse suite of samples to be automatically tested in a short amount of time. During the project, three specific initiatives have been be integrated with the research to capitalize on the collaborative nature of the project: (1) a student exchange program for 2 Ph.D. graduate students at CSM and UW; (2) a diversity initiative implemented through recruiting a female graduate student at UW; and (3) an educational initiative featuring integration and evaluation of more “high tech” sorption-based soil classification modules into graduate level geotechnical graduate course Unsaturated Soil Mechanics at CSM.
